ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning about ancient philosophers and their major philosophical theories. Develop skills of critical thinking and philosophical analysis.
How to write a philosophy paper.
Philosophical writing and thinking skills ability to think clearly, follow a logical argument, identify the flaws, and be able to stick your neck out and assert what you believe in and defend it.
I learned how to write a philosophy paper. I learned about ancient philosophers and their worldviews.
I learned much about Ancient Greek (and Roman) schools of thought and how they relate to our modern-day.

I learned 1) specific arguments and theories of Ancient Greek Philosophers, 2) ways of making philosophical arguments, breaking arguments down into their component parts, and thinking philosophically, and 3)

Provided overview of key works of Ancient (mainly Greek) philosophy.  Mainly Plato and Aristotle.

Saw how major themes of philosophy are developed.
I learned a lot about the anceint Greek philosophersPlato, Aristotle, etc.and their ideologies. I developed skills in philosophical writing.
A very intellectually engaging course. I become better at writing philosophy papers and discussing readings in section.
Synthesis/overview of ancient Greek philosophy

Survey course in Western philosophy from the pre-Socratics to the academic Stoics (with a main focus on Socrates/Plato and Aristotle). Topics included ancient metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, and some political philosophy. Received great feedback on how to write a general philosophy paper.

I learned a broad introduction to philosophical thought from the Presocratics up until Epicurus. I learned how to write a philosophy essay, the structure, effective argumentative strategies, and how to communicate philosophical arguments in a small seminar setting. I learned how to interpret Aristotle's arguments, and how to craft effective personal counterarguments to ideas put forth by philosophers like Plato and Aristotle.
Fairly sturdy knowledge of ancient Greek philosophy, with very good handpicked readings and optional text. This is quite a good class for being a requirement.
I received writing and thinking skills.
Given that it was my first philosophy course, I learned a lot regarding all of the different philosophers and their theories.

Before taking this course I had no idea how to write a philosophy paper; now I feel very comfortable tackling them. I also learned about ancient Greek philosophers. For me, it was a case of not knowing just how much I didn't know, and the amount I learned, not only about each individual philosopher but how they fit together and built off (criticized and improved) each other's ideas, surprised me.
I was given a basic overview of ancient philosophy in this class. Like most other philosophy classes, PHIL 125 pushed me to think critically and develop better argumentative essays.
Reading and writing about philosophy
I learned how to write philosophy papers, how to structure sound philosophical arguments, and how to approach broad philosophical questions.
I learned how to read closely and careful. I gained skills in writing philosophy papers.
I learned the foundations of Western thought.
Thorough overview of Ancient philosophers
None

Knowledge of the biographies, positions and theories of several seminal ancient Greek and Roman philosophers;  skills for introductory academic paper writing. Insight: ancient philosophy is interesting and important for so much for the genealogical purposes. The theories are bold, original, sometimes deeply intuitive; learning about them has made me interrogate my own originality and resourcefulness in knowledge construction.
How to think in a philosophical sense (which was a good contrast to all the cs, math, and econ classes i was taking). I also learned about different philosophies, philosophers and history.
I learned great reading and writing skills, and how to read ancient literature.

I appreciated the scope of the course  it felt appropriate for an intro level course, and I gained quite a bit of insight into ancient philosophers and their theories. Skill wise, I certainly learned how to write a philosophy paper and dissect a philosophical argument.
As the course name suggests, intro to ancient philosophy, and how to write a philosophy essay.
Perhaps the most noteworthy skill I developed was learning to write a philosophy paper, as well as reading large quantities of difficult texts.
Analyzing texts from ancient philosophers and writing philosophy essays.
I learned about the ideas of various thinkers and the evolution of philosophical thought, primarily in Ancient Greece.

Developed an understanding of Plato, Socrates, Epicurus, Aristotle, Stoicism, and Skepticism. Learned much about the development of scientific and philosophical thought. Learned how to write a philosophy paper. Learned how to clearly formulate and carry out an argument.

I gained a good foundation of ancient philosophy and learned how to write philosophy papers. It was a good introduction course that provided insight on the topic of philosophy as well as on whether I like this material.
A basic understanding and working knowledge of notable ancient texts, historians, and thinkers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Professor Inwood is definitely a strength of the course. He explains the reading very well in a way that makes them more comprehensible.

There is a decent amount of reading, so I would not take this course if you were not prepared to do a lot of reading and rereading.
Very enjoyable lectures. great TAs

Strength: a lot of practice on philosophy writing. You will get good at it.
Weakness: Some reading is a bit dense, especially Aristotle. Pre-Socratic philosophers are also a bit less interesting
The reading needn't be so intense. The lecture material was more than sufficient, and some of the readings were absurdly difficult to understand, to the point where it felt useless to attempt.

Strengths: Professor Inwood is an amazing lecturer, there isn't too much work and all the essays are fun to write and have good prompts.

Weaknesses: Sometimes discussions felt a little redundant or unproductive, but the key principles of the course are very interesting.

I would appreciate it if more time, both in lecture and section, was devoted to teaching philosophical skills (how to read dense passages, efficient ways to annotate, logical/philosophical techniques), rather than just the content of the arguments and theories that each philosopher posited. Especially considering this is an intro class, I think many students would have a richer understanding of ancient philosophy if more of an emphasis was placed on philosophical skills.

There's a lot of great readings, but there are a lot of readings. And having only three essays was nice, but also a little scary that three grades (and the final we were supposed to have) made up our entire grade. For me, it would have been helpful (since I am a procrastinator) if there were mandatory check-ins or progress points for the essays. Also the second and third essay were too bunched up right before the final. Moving all the essays earlier a bit would have been nice.

Clear overview, at an introductory level.  

Can help see connections to more developed ideas in other phil classes.

Lectures are very linear -- for better and worse.  Clear and understandable, but not that challenging.
There were no great strengths or alarming weaknesses. It was just your typical philosophy class. I'm not the biggest fan of ancient philosophy though, so that might impact my opinion a bit.
Professor is great at integrating readings into the class and you can clearly tell that he is passionate about the material. Office hours were promoted very little.

No sense of context
No relationship between assessments and lectures or sections
Too much variation between sections

The strengths of this course were the fascinating content and the writing sections, which were really well-structured for student learning. However, the lectures were sometimes a bit dull/redundant, and we rarely got through all of the material in section, so it required a lot of catching up on our own time.

Strengths: The seminars were so helpful. This is where all of the inter student discussion took place, and who your TF is will determine a lot about how this course goes. You are able to develop a close relationship with your TF as they guide you through learning how to write a philosophy paper from scratch. Lectures were very interesting, and Brad was wonderful in his ability to answer his questions. 

Weaknesses: Brad's level of engagement with the students was minimal, the TFs graded all essays so the grading was not equal across all sections. Again, really make sure you have a close relationship with your TF because they will be the ones grading you on practically everything.

No huge weaknesses other than the variability of TA. It seems that some groups had incredible TAs who provided a lot of handouts and review materials, and other groups had TAs who weren't quite as supportive.
There was a lot of content, but low engagement in class because there were no powerpoints/few useful visuals/little time for absorbing information.
I think it was very helpful to have a discussion section to engage with the material more in depth.

One problem with the course is a gap between when the paper was assigned, when we were expected to begin working on it in discussion section, and then a rush to get TF feedback before submitting it. This improved after mid-semester feedback, but is worth reiterating here. The main improvement to this would be to get going on the paper faster in section so there is more time for review and editing. Also, the content is discussion section often fell well behind lecture. 
This course is strong in the revisions and feedback itself, at least in the case of my TF. The lectures are consistently engaging and the reading is relevant (sometimes quite long and sometimes quite short).
Sections are great especially with Jennifer, but lectures are not the most engaging

The sections for this course are extremely helpful. They help condense the information presented in lecture and my TF really helped with writing papers. Since the final exam would have covered all the material, it would have been nice to have seen a midterm like it before the final.
The course is interesting and the lectures are helpful in breaking down the readings. I think the reading schedule was a little confusing at times and some more clarity wouldve helped.
The course should focus less on the pre-Socratics and post-Aristotelians and more on the most foundational texts.
Lecture's weren't always very productive
Record the lectures!

Strength: fascinating texts parsed by an extremely knowledgeable professor
Weakness: too much breadth, not much time for examining arguments closely

strengths: content was interesting 
weakness: this lecture style was kind of the instructor rambling so it was very hard to follow at times
At first we had a very mediocre TF, but it got a lot better once we got Jennifer. So I would make sure to say to have sections that are engaging like Jennifer did.

Strengths: great TAs, interesting lectures, good instruction for paper writing
Weaknesses: lectures could be a bit more engaging

It felt like we spent the entire semester talking about just Plato/Socrates and Aristotle. I get that those two are pretty important, but going into a class that was supposed to introduce all of ancient philosophy, I thought we'd spend more time covering a broader range of thinkers. Also, we didn't end up taking the final exam because of covid complications, but the idea of matching passages of text to the text they came from felt like a very inept way of measuring what we took from the course.

If possible, I would like a general review in terms of a written outline at the end of the term or after each philosopher. It is easy to get lost in lectures and going back to watch all lectures doesn't seem very efficient.
The TA program is very strong. I do feel like theres so much content covered and only small portions are talked about is talked in lecture, understandably.
There should be more instruction on how to write a philosophy essay if this is meant to be an introductory course.

I liked the lecture/section structure, I think it gave a good balance of teaching styles and allowed students to learn in different environments. The scope of the class what I expected it to be, and I enjoyed the essay prompts.

This course, I thought, was much too focused on the history of philosophy and science than it was in actual philosophy. The class schedule was far too skewed towards Plato, Socrates, and Aristotle, and the first two weeksgoing over a handful of minor, insubstantial philosophers I found to be a waste. Also, the readings were very disproportionate. Reading all of Plato's Republic over three classes was way to much, and it made me stop doing the readings completely for a while.

The strength of this course is the discussion sections. It was a good way to engage with the material and gauge my understanding. The weaknesses are that the lectures can be a bit hard to engage with and the readings are awfully long. Sometimes its difficult to fully engage with the material and understand all of it when you have to read so much in such a short period of time. I understand that this is an introductory course, and thus theres a lot of material to get through, but maybe it would be better if the course was more focused on fewer, selected topics so that we can engage with the material better and gain a deeper understanding, rather than just superficial knowledge.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to those interested in learning about ancient philosophy. The name of the course is a good indicator of what you will be learning about.
Yes, but be prepared for intellectual challenge and a large reading load
Yes if you like talking about philosophy and practice your reasoning skills.

There is a lot of reading, but you don't really have to do all of it to keep up with the pace of the course. I would say take this class especially if you really enjoy engaging with philosophical thought and reading, but even if you don't the class is really engaging and entertaining.
Yes. This course was very interesting, and it made me a better thinker.
Good for someone who has never taken a philosophy course before or wants a good survey of the Greek philosophers.
Yes, if they were interested in ancient Greek philosophy.
Yes.  Good intro to Ancient Philosophy, necessary for Phil major or and serious student of philosophy.
I would recommend it. It is a great writing credit, and the material is quite interesting. Not too much writing eitherjust three 5-7 page papers.

no-one would ever 'recommend' this course
it's compulsory

If you are a philosophy major, it is a requirement, and you will be glad that it is one, as you will learn a lot. If you are not in the philosophy major, perhaps I would recommend this course, although only if you already have a strong interest in ancient philosophy. Otherwise, I think there are probably more interesting introductory philosophy courses, if you want to try out a philosophy course.

I would recommend this course if you are looking for a broad introduction to the ancient philosophers. It is not particularly intriguing in any way, it is an intro course. You will learn how to read and write philosophy from scratch, so if you have taken other philosophy classes before maybe choose a more niche class. Otherwise, this class did exactly what it advertised, it was a broad introduction.

If you care about ancient Greek philosophy, this course is rather good, especially under Inwood. However, if you have no care for ancient Greek  philosophy, don't conceptualize this as THE intro course. you can get started elsewhere.
I would recommend this course if someone was interested in philosophy and needed to fill the prerequisites; otherwise, no.

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in the material. Although this course is an intro course, I don't think the course would be interesting to someone who didn't find that material interesting.

Absolutely. As a writing credit, it is a solid introduction to philosophy papersan enjoyably alternative to the more stereotypical English papers that allow you to focus primarily on the quality of your ideas and justification for them, instead of elegant presentation. The lectures, too, are engaging and interesting throughout the course which aligns well with the relevant reading. After taking the course, you feel confident in your understanding of the ideas of the ancient world and understand references to Plato, Aristotle, and how the hedonistic Epicureans and the 'living in accordance with nature' Stoics.
Not if you just need a writing credit, this course grades essays unnecessarily hard its actually kind of ridiculous.
If you like ancient philosophy, yes. If not, the works are very dense.
Yes, I would recommend this course to a student who wants to be introduced to philosophical thinking and writing. The course is very interesting and a great starting point for philosophy.
Yes. It was a reading heavy course so staying on top of the readings is what made the course enjoyable. I learned a lot about ancient philosophers and it was very interesting.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the canonical works of Ancient Greek and Roman philosophy.
Yes! I really enjoyed Professor Inwood's interesting lectures and kind demeanor.
For a philosophy major
No; you can learn everything in the course by simply reading the philosophers on your own

I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in fundamental questions of reality, knowledge, ethics, but have had little exposure to ancient philosophy. For anyone who worries that they are too advanced in philosophy to take an intro class: take it. The quality of discussions will vary, but the quality of the lectures and readings will not disappoint.
Unless you need it for your major, I would not recommends. I took it for fun as a writing credit and the class itself was not that appealing for me because it was slightly unorganized.
Yes I would, Professor Inwood is good and the materials are very interesting.
If youre not planning on majoring in philosophy but would like a bit of background on Plato/Aristotle/etc, definitely.

If you're curious about philosophy, I'd recommend starting elsewhere. This course wasn't horrible, but it felt like a bit of a trudge to me, and I usually love philosophy. Even waiting a semester for intro to modern is probably a more exciting and interesting way to dip your toes in the philosophical water. Of course, if classics and the ancient world are your thing, by all means take this course--you might love it. But for anyone else, just keep in mind that there are many other types of philosophy that Yale has to offer if this isn't your thing. If this had been my first philosophy course, I probably would not have majored in philosophy.
Yes,  for non-majors more so as Credit/D
Yes, especially those interested in philosophy.
It's a great introduction to ancient philosophy and the writing focus means you have ample opportunity to improve your philosophical writing skills.

No. Anyone interested in philosophy but not sure if they want to major in it should not have this as their first philosophy class. It is a requirement for the major, but I should've chosen something else in hindsight.
If youre interested in philosophy or just want to see if you like philosophy, this is a good introduction class to take. However, I wouldnt say its super exciting topics.
